Posts.Content: samiam40 wrote: Despite not getting any particularly "good" news at my meeting with the doctor tonight, I feel strangely calm and optimistic.  Although I am still waiting for some key pieces of information from my pathology report (whether tumor is ER, PR, HER+), the surgical portion of my case is decided.  I went in knowing I wanted bilat mx and she certainly didn't try to talk me out of it.  They are setting up meetings with 2 plastic surgeons for me and doing some pre-op tests (blood, BRCA and chest xray).  I should be getting my surgery in the next 3-4 weeks. After the surgery, I will be offered chemo (which I will do) and possibly an anti-estrogen drug if the tumor is ER+.  I won't need radiation unless 4 nodes come out positive, the tumor is unexpectedly large or it is close to the chest wall and/or with bad margins.  The worst part of the whole consult was when I asked about prognosis stats.  She said that best case scenario, tumor 1.6 cm or smaller, no node involvement, my doing chemo, was a 7-12 % lifetime recurrence rate.  That is worse than I expected.   However, now that I have a plan, I feel much better, calmer, even optimistic.  I can't explain it.  I guess the waiting really is worse than dealing with the reality of the disease.  If that helps anyone going through this, I will be glad.   -Samiam40 Dx 1/12/09 @ age 40, IDC 2.6 cm, Stage 2a, Grade 1, 0/10 nodes, ER+/PR+/HER2-, Onco 14, BRCA neg. Bilat mx w/TEs 2/3/09. CMFx6 3/2-6/15/09. Zometa 5/09-9/10. Tamox 7/09-present Exchange w/gummy bears 9/9/09. N/A recon 12/16/09. Log in to post a reply

Second, for those wondering about costs, the hospital billed $2,200 "globally" to BCBS.  I paid $534 which was the balance due on my $1,000 deductible for the year, and BCBS paid about $415.00.  The hospital must have written off the rest

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 08:34PM - edited Feb 16, 2009 08:35PM by samiam40 I thought about getting a 2nd opinion from my breast surgeon but knew she was one of the best, so I elected not to.  I did get opinions from 2 different plastic surgeons.  I had an appointment with an oncologist last week who my husband and I really like.  But, when I asked her what she thought about my getting 2nd opinion, she not only gave me her blessing and vetted my choice, she had her staff set up my appointment with the other guy who was booked solid for 2 weeks and moved around a bunch of other appointments to see me.  Doctors are not at all offended when you seek a 2nd opinion.  In fact, they often encourage it.  It's all about your health and your comfort level.  If you'd feel better getting a fresh perspective, you should do so.  You could call the ACS for recommendations, or even ask your current doctors who else they would recommend.  Honestly, it won't offend them.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 11:45AM samiam40 wrote: My very limited understanding of the subject is that cancerous tumors have their own blood supply.  So if radiologists see a tumor that is star shaped or appears to have tenticles, they can be pretty sure that it is malignant.  Whether that is the case 100% of the time or if there can be false positives, I do not know.  I understand it is heartbreaking when a loved one gets a diagnosis of cancer, but take a deep breath.  It is not a death sentence.  Everyone on this site has been through just such a diagnosis and the vast majority of us will survive and live long and productive lives. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 05:54PM - edited Feb 6, 2009 05:56PM by samiam40 A couple more pointers for those about to do the bilat mx route.  When they discharge you, have them take as much of the extra cotton and gauze as possible out of the cami.  Its so tight anyway, that even a little extra cotton makes it just that much harder to breathe.  Have someone around to help you get up out of chairs.  That is still the hardest and most painful thing--trying to get up without using your arms to lift yourself.  Finally, allow people to wait on you hand and foot as much as you are able.  If there is ever a time you deserve to be waited on, THIS IS IT.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 07:23PM - edited Feb 9, 2009 07:38PM by samiam40 Well, I finally feel ready to give a full report from my bilat mx with tissue expanders on Tuesday 2/3.  The surgery took 5 hours.  The initial report was that it went well and the nodes appeared to be clear.  After the surgery, I was in a tremendous amount of pain, couldn't move my arms enough to get myself out of bed and felt like a Hummer was parked on my chest.  Tried to eat some dinner but got instantly nauseous.  They gave me lots of pain drugs, anti-nausea drugs and muscle relaxants and generally treated me like a queen at the overnight surgery suite where I recovered. I was sent home by noon the next day but spent most of the first 48 hours after surgery drifting in and out of narcotic-induced sleep.  Thursday, Friday and Saturday were spent mostly in the bed and recliner, trying to find a comfortable position. By Sunday, I really felt better and like I turned the corner as far as pain, so I decided to get off the narcotics.  Am now managing pain with just motrin and valium.  Today I saw my plastic surgeon and she took out 2 drains.  I still have 2 left which she predicts will be out by the end of the week.  She did say that the skin looked a bit raw and blistered in one area because my breast surgeon was so agressive in taking out tissue that it left the remaining skin in a bit of a mess.  She was optimistic that I wouldn't lose the compromised skin since I hadn't already, and suggested I rub A&D ointment into the blister to keep it moist. I got pathology reports back today also.  My breast surgeon (did I mention she was agressive?) took out 10 nodes during my sentinal node biopsy.  2 sets of 3 on the cancer side and 4 on the prophy side.  All came back negative.  There was no sign of cancer on the prophy side. The IDC tumor on the right side was a bit larger than we expected (2.6 cm vs. 1.6), but I'm not sure that really changes my treatment plan much.  I meet with an oncologist in 3 days to discuss. Overall, a decent experience so far.  My upper chest still hurts like he*l, but less like a Hummer is parked there, and more like a Mini-Cooper.  To anyone about to undergo a similar procedure, please know that you can totally handle it, just take it one day at a time.  As with most things in life, I have learned, the waiting and worrying is worse than the actual reality.  Peace, love & healing to all.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 08:10AM - edited Feb 22, 2009 08:16AM by samiam40 Had my surgery 2/3.  Getting sick beforehand was my worst fear too and I have 4 germy little kids who were all in some stage of viral illness.  So, I took tons of Vitamin C for a week before the surgery and stayed away from the gym and washed my hands like a maniac and lo and behold, I stayed well.  I've read a couple of you are taking off your nail polish?  Double check with your hospital/surgery center whether this is necessary.  Mine said no finger nail polish, but toe nail polish was fine.  So, I treated myself to a pedicure the day before and it felt great.  I also got my hair cut and colored--like Dani and Mooma.  It's just one less thing to worry about later on. Bitchiness-that's totally understandable.  I felt completely on edge and snappy, but Xanax was my friend and the doctor even OK'd my taking one the morning of the surgery, so that would be recommendation. Good luck to all of you with upcoming surgeries. P.S. I'm not quite 3 weeks out from surgery.  Don't yet feel what I would consider "great" but most everything is do-able.  I've been off pain meds since day 4 and now just take motrin and the occasional valium as a muscle relaxant.  All drains are out, I'm driving, back to being Mom and going into work for an hour or so a day.  Still need a nap in the afternoon and spend most of my time off my feet, but you will bounce back before you know it.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 01:43PM - edited Feb 17, 2009 01:45PM by samiam40 I had cancer on the right side, and a bilateral mx.  I elected to have sentinal node biopsy on both sides, the cancerous one and the "healthy" one.  This decision is controversial.  However, everyone has a sentinal node on each side (or more than one in my case) whether they have cancer or not.  It's just the "gatekeeper" node, the first one cancer would reach if it were metastasizing.  Hindsight is 20/20 so I'm not sure whether I made the right decision in getting the SNB on the healthy side.  No cancer was found in the left side, and now I have pain and a giant scar there from having 4 sentinal nodes removed.  I had 6 sentinal nodes removed from the right side--I guess I'm just an extra sentinal kinda gal.   However, if you are getting a mastectomy, you only get one chance to do a SNB.  If you elect not to, and they do find cancer in the "healthy" breast, you have to go back and get an axillary dissection of the whole node system, which is a much more complicated process and comes with a higher risk of lymphadema. Good luck whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 11:00AM - edited Feb 24, 2009 11:03AM by samiam40 I was diagnosed with ADH and LCIS in the right breast in 2002.  I also have a strong family history of bc.  I was offered and declined both bilat mx and tamox, and instead elected close surveillance.  At the time I was only 33 and wanted more children.  I have since had 2 more kids, but I also developed invasive ductal carcinoma.  Surveillance has its limitations--even with mammograms and exams every 6 months, my cancer was only detected on MRI and not until it was 2.6 cm and invasive. Your age might play into it your decision-making.  I was resistant to taking tamox b/c I was so young.  If you are past child bearing, I would definitely consider it.  See how you tolerate it.  Some people hate it--others do fine with no side effects.   Prophylactic surgery was too radical for me and even though I have developed cancer, I know that declining the mx was still the right decision to make in my situation. Best of luck to you whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Atypia Hyperplasia-Now What? mkd1061 Petitegal127

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2009 02:37PM samiam40 wrote: Kim, I had dense breasts (despite their having virtually no volume after breastfeeding 4 children) and mammograms and u/s were useless.  They all came up clear.  MRI, however, detected my breast cancer and is a vast diagnostic improvement for dense breasts. Recovery time does depend on what of surgery you have.  If you do delayed reconstruction, you should heal much faster.  If you have tissue expanders implanted at the time of the mastectomy to preserve and stretch the skin, your recovery will be tougher.  Flap surgeries (diep, tram) are a whole different ballgame with a lot longer recovery time. Whether your mx is prophy or not, you can keep the skin--it's called a skin-sparing mastectomy.  I believe if your mast is prophy, you can keep the nipple.  However, if you have already developed cancer, you definitely cannot because it contains breast tissue. I would not recommend "waiting until breast cancer develops."  You might end up like me, waiting too long, and not being diagnosed until the cancer is invasive.  A diagnosis of DCIS (pre-invasive) is much easier to deal with and considered completely "curable" with appropriate treatment.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 09:28AM - edited Feb 18, 2009 09:29AM by samiam40 I experienced it.  I don't know how common it is, but I had a mammogram and ultrasound that were clear in mid-December.  I went for an MRI on 12/30 due to family history and it detected a lump that ended up being a 2.6 cm invasive cancer.  I am not trying to scare you--just answering your question.  Mammograms and ultrasounds are good at detecting some cancers, but don't find everything.  The odds are very good, however, that your lump will be benign.  Most are. Something else to consider, if MRI is not an option due to cost, is getting a biopsy of the lump.  Getting a negative report back from a biopsy could give you more piece of mind.

I was on vacation and in the men's underwear section of a department store buying socks for my son when I got the call--very surreal.  Also, I had been 100% positive that the MRI would be fine--so much for intuition.  Anyway, the only 2 pieces of information that I got from the doctor was that there were suspicious abnormalities on both sides and that the radiologist did not believe it was a false positive. I'm intrigued by your doctor's comment that the "worst" it could be is DCIS.  On the one hand, that doesn't sound too terrible, right?  On the other, DCIS is not necessarily a picnic based on some of the stories from other women I've been reading.  On the third hand (!), I have also read that MRI is bad at detecting DCIS.  I don't know what to think anymore.  I'll send this message and then see if I can figure out the private message function to send you my email address so we can chat more if you want.  Also, I'm sure others will weigh in soon about what to expect at an MRI guided biopsy. Hang in there--we'll get through it. -Samiam

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 11:24PM - edited Feb 15, 2009 11:25PM by samiam40 I don't know what the chances are--I wish I had a crystal ball.  I will share my story though. I had an excisional biopsy in 2002 that left a ridge of scar tissue.  My doctor examined me every 6 months and I had clear mammograms every 6 months.  Unfortunately, I was recently diagnosed with IDC and the tumor was found exactly behind the ridge of scar tissue from the prior biopsy.  My mammos were also all clear and the cancer was only detected on MRI. I am not trying to scare you, the odds are overwhelmingly good that your lump will be boringly benign.  But do be vigilant and get the lump biopsied.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 10:31PM samiam40 wrote: Movinon, I am in a similar situation.  I was diagnosed on Monday with IDC, am 40 and have 4 children ranging in age from 3-11.  Personally, it didn't occur to me to do anything other than bilateral mx with reconstruction.  I want it gone and never to go through this again.  Of course, I am worried about how I will look afterward.  But for me the trade off is worth it.  The plastic surgeons where I live do not do simulatenous reconstruction.  What they do is put in tissue expanders at the time of the mastectomy to preserve the skin, fill them over the course of a few months, and then, when you have recovered from your original surgery and chemo, either swap them out for more permanent implants or do the tram/diep surgery.  I went into this process determined to get a diep.  The more I learn about the extensive recovery and risk involved, especially since I have young children to care for, the more I am leaning toward implants (plus a tummy tuck as a present to me when all this is over). Everybody's situation is different, though, and you have to make the decision that feels right for you.  I wish you much luck, and if you want to chat or ask me anything, feel free to pm me. -Samiam
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, Mastectomy or Bi-Lateral Mastectomy movinOn movinOn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 10:00AM samiam40 wrote: movinon, I too am worried about being able to be active again after all this is over.  I run, spin, lift weights, and plan to continue doing so into my old age.   However, I also want to do everything I can to make sure I am around into my old age.  That is why I am going with the bilat mx.  I've heard too many stories about people who had one breast done and then later cancer was found in the other.  Plus, I have LCIS which is a precursor for cancer in either breast and the MRI showed a small spot of concern in my left side that they deemed too small to biopsy, so who knows what that could turn into. My doctor said that because my cancer was invasive, chemo would be offered to me even if my nodes were clear.  I plan to take it.  Everyone has to make the decision based on their own risk tolerance.  Personally, I am willing to live with a few months of hell and the risk of serious side effects to make sure my bc is gone.  Since my tumor came back er+, I will also be offered and will accept tamoxifine.  As far as the implants vs diep/tram flap procedure, here's what I understand in very broad generalities, keeping in mind everyone's situation is different.  Tissue expanders is a fairly routine surgery that takes a few hours vs. flap which is microsurgery and takes the better part of a day.  TE requires you to be in the hospital for a day or two; flap is closer to a week in the hospital.  TE has a couple week recovery period when you are pretty much laid up in bed recovering; flap is six solid weeks of recovery time.  Again, I'm sure people on the board will have different experiences and I would recommend you listen to everyone and make the decision you think is best for you. Please feel free to pm me if you want to talk more.  I am always bumping up against the 5 posts per day rule, and am often unable to reply to people because of that.  Hang in there and keep us posted as to what's going on with you.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, Mastectomy or Bi-Lateral Mastectomy movinOn movinOn

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 10:07PM - edited Mar 15, 2009 10:09PM by samiam40 Michele, 4 weeks was the magic mark for me.  I so understand what you are feeling.  I am a busy mom of 4 and I expected to be able to bounce back right away, but it takes time.  Are you doing your wall walking exercises?  That helps with the range of motion problem, as does just reaching up and stretching from time to time.  The TEs do get more comfortable also.  Whole hours go by and I forget they are there.  But most of the time I am always aware of them, though I'd describe it more as discomfort now than pain. Now that I am about 6 weeks out, I can even take off over the head shirts, albeit very slowly, and reach up to high shelves to get things.  So, know that it does get better, you just have to give it time. I'm wondering why you would need chemo with DCIS.  That would be very unusual.  Did your pathology report find some IDC in there?  Sending you healing vibes, Samiam40

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 10:08PM - edited Feb 15, 2009 10:09PM by samiam40 Yes, they take out the nodes and the amount varies widely depending on your lymphatic system.  Sometimes what looks like a single sentinal node on the film is actually group of nodes clustered together.  Hence, I had 2 groups of 3 nodes removed from my right side and a cluster of 4 nodes removed from left.  They have to take out everything that "lights up" from the dye.  For this reason, I had 2 sets of drains on each side-one for the mastectomy and one for the node removal.  If you have a bunch of nodes removed, you may very well get drains, and they definitely suck, but it's only for a short time.
